The @CorncrakeLife project aims to improve conservation status of the #corncrake. It works with land managers and communities to conserve and improve the quality of corncrake habitats, and the ecosystem services they provide like clean water, carbon storage and wider biodiversity

How to spot #birdflu in your flock 🐓
Symptoms include:
🐔swollen head
🦆discolouration of neck and throat
🐤loss of appetite
🦃respiratory distress
🐓diarrhoea
🥚fewer eggs laid
These symptoms vary between species

The female Holly Blue butterfly lays eggs at the base of holly and ivy flower buds that are growing in warm and sunny conditions. 

The larvae feed mostly on the developing flower buds, berries and leaves.

Look out for them in open woodland, hedgerows, parks and mature gardens🦋

The Holly Blue butterfly relies on holly and ivy.

The adult butterflies emerge in early spring and a second generation appears in summer. They can be seen congregating around holly in spring and Ivy in the late summer.

Learn more @PollinatorPlan at🦋🦋🦋 https://t.co/JIzhOb9RYW https://t.co/AdD9DzfCHY

The main veterinary medicines changes include:
Rules on use and manufacturing 
Advertising and labelling
Pharmacovigilance rules
EU product database
Rules on wholesale of veterinary medicines
Rules on prescribing
Validity of prescriptions for antimicrobials and medicated feed
The incidence of Bovine Viral Diarrhoea test positive animals decreased this year to just 0.03% from 0.66% in 2013 – the first year of the compulsory phase of the eradication programme

In bloom from June to September, you can find the native Irish flower self-seeding around farms.

🐝Where Knapweed is established and is not detrimental to crops, it is best left to look after the pollinators - the bees, butterflies, beetles and flies - who need it to survive.🦋

A recent study found that more than half of visits from bumblebees to field margin flowers were to Knapweed.🐝

Also known as Black Knapweed, Hardheads, Blackheads and Mullach dubh, this perennial plant also provides seeds for birds after flowering.🐦🌱

🌸https://t.co/JIzhOb9RYW https://t.co/X1gi9HUadX

Farmers and farms play a vital role in protecting our wild pollinators

Our Protecting Farmland Pollinators European Innovation Partnership (EIP) helps farmers be more pollinator friendly

We also funded a Farmland Project Officer to support positive biodiversity actions

The requirement for a phytosanitary certificate for all other regulated plants and plant products including most fruits, veg, cut foliage, flowers and seeds, has been deferred from April 1, 2021 until January 1, 2022.

Checks on high priority plants and plants and plant products, including ware potatoes and second hand machinery, due to take place at Border Control Posts in GB from July 1, 2021 will continue to be checked at Places of Destination until January 1, 2022. https://t.co/4Zk61XyrqO

Since January 1, all high priority plants and plant products including ware potatoes and second hand machinery require a phytosanitary certificate and pre-notification for export to GB.

This remains unchanged going forward. https://t.co/Y0sTgNqTPl

The UK Government recently announced a revised timetable for the introduction of Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) requirements and controls for exports from EU member states into GB.

If you are exporting second hand/used machinery to a country outside the EU, there are specific requirements:

💻You must register with us

📋Apply for a phytosanitary certificate

🔩Machinery needs to be inspected

➡️Learn more on #Brexit trade changes: https://t.co/bJeCwQFUdS

If you are importing second hand/used machinery into Ireland from a non-EU country, there are specific requirements to protect our #planthealth

You must:
🚜Be registered with us
💻Be registered with TRACES NT
📋Have a phytosanitary certificate
📅Notify us 24-hours before arrival https://t.co/gvol1xhebh

It is required by law that second hand/used machinery imported to Ireland from EU and non-EU countries is clean and free of organic matter.

⚖️You must:

🚜Get written confirmation that purchased machinery is clean and inspected

🔩Clean and disinfect machinery prior to first use https://t.co/OHIrUoekqf

There are specific requirements for the trade of second hand/used #machinery🚜

Any soil, #plant debris or organic matter attached to machinery may contain bacteria, disease or pests that can damage crops

➡️See post #Brexit requirements in #trader notice:
https://t.co/1eSFlhUZOT https://t.co/CXaPjCBgiy
